{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16957,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salix uva-ursi, commonly known as creeping willow, appreciates consistently moist soil, especially during its growing season in the spring and summer. It prefers not to dry out completely between waterings, so it’s important to keep the soil slightly damp. However, the plant does not thrive in waterlogged conditions, so ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent root rot. During the fall and winter, you can reduce the frequency of watering as the plant's growth slows down. Monitoring soil moisture is key to maintaining optimal hydration for this willow species."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salix uva-ursi thrives in areas with full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and health, provide it with at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. If you’re in a hotter climate, offering it some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch from the intense midday sun. In areas with cooler temperatures, ensuring plenty of sun exposure will support vigorous growth. Adjust its placement according to your climate conditions to ensure the plant receives balanced sunlight throughout the growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salix uva-ursi is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This will help maintain its shape and promote a healthy, attractive appearance. Focus on removing any dead, damaged, or diseased branches first. You can also trim back any overly long branches to encourage bushier growth. Keeping its growth under control with regular pruning will help support a dense and healthy plant structure. Be sure to use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and minimize stress on the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bearberry willow","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","North America"],"other_name":["bearberry willow"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Caterpillars"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Salix uva-ursi"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16174,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Celosia argentea thrives in moderately moist soil, so it's important to water it regularly but avoid overwatering. Allow the top inch of the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season, which includes spring and summer, water more frequently to support its growth and flowering. In the cooler months, reduce the watering frequency as the plant's water needs decrease. Always ensure good drainage and use a pot with drainage holes if kept indoors. Mulching can help retain soil moisture, but take care not to allow water to stand at the base of the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Celosia argentea requires full sunlight to thrive, needing at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. When planted outdoors, choose a location that receives abundant sunlight, as this promotes vibrant foliage and flowering. Indoors, place the plant near a south-facing window to maximize light exposure. Insufficient light can lead to poor growth and reduced blooming, so consider supplementing with grow lights if natural sunlight is inadequate. While Celosia can tolerate partial shade, especially in hot climates, optimal flowering and health are achieved with ample direct sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Celosia argentea is relatively straightforward. Deadheading, or the removal of spent flowers, is essential to encourage continuous blooming and maintain the plant's aesthetic appeal. Regularly check the plant for faded flowers and cut them back to the nearest leaf node. This process boosts new growth and refreshes the plant's appearance. If the plant becomes leggy or overgrown, you can trim back up to one-third of its stems. Pruning during the growing season (spring and summer) is ideal, as this is when the plant is most vigorous. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Quail Grass","description":"Celosia argentea, commonly known as plumed cockscomb, or the silver cock's comb, is a herbaceous plant of tropical origin, and is known for its very bright colors. In India and China it is known as a troublesome weed.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Africa","India"],"other_name":["Quail Grass"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Celosia argentea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17257,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salix × sepulcralis, commonly known as weeping willow, thrives in moist environments, which means regular watering is essential, especially during dry spells. Ensure that the soil remains consistently moist but be cautious of waterlogging, which can damage the roots. Generally, water the plant deeply once a week, increasing the frequency during hot, dry weather. In the absence of rain, the amount of water needed can vary based on soil type and local climate, but as a rule of thumb, soaking the top 6-12 inches of soil is a good practice for healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salix × sepulcralis requires full sun to partial shade for optimal growth. It thrives best in locations where it can receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch and minimize stress on the plant. While the tree can tolerate some shade, insufficient sunlight may reduce its vigor or lead to a less dense foliage. Therefore, when choosing a planting site, ensure it's exposed to ample sunlight while also considering the tree's mature size and space requirements."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salix × sepulcralis is vital for maintaining its graceful weeping form and overall health. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring before the tree begins to leaf out. Focus on removing any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to promote better air circulation, which helps prevent diseases. Additionally, trim any branches that detract from the desired shape of the tree. Use clean, sharp tools to make your cuts, ideally at a slight angle just above a bud. Regular pruning will encourage new growth and maintain its attractive appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Golden Weeping Willow","description":"The Salix sepulcralis group is a cultivar group containing all cultivars of hybrids between Salix alba and Salix babylonica. The sepulcralis or × sepulcralis trees are sometimes referred to as white weeping willow or glaucous weeping willow in reference to the mixed appearance from the parent species. It was first described by L. Simonkai in 1890 from trees growing in Romania. The group contains both weeping and nonweeping cultivars, though the best-known of its cultivars is...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Golden Weeping Willow"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Canker","Leaf spot","Borer"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Salix × sepulcralis"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17952,"attracts":["Bees","Hummingbirds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Justicia aurea, commonly known as the golden shrimp plant, thrives in evenly moist soil. It's essential to water this plant regularly to maintain consistent moisture; however, ensure the soil has good drainage and never becomes waterlogged. Water when the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch, generally about once a week, but adjust the frequency depending on the plant's environmental conditions such as temperature and humidity. In dry conditions or during active growth phases, more frequent watering may be necessary. Reduce watering during the plant’s dormant periods in cooler months."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Justicia aurea prefers bright, indirect sunlight. It can tolerate some direct sun, especially in the morning when the light is less intense. Too much direct sunlight, particularly in the afternoon, can scorch the leaves. Conversely, insufficient light may lead to leggy growth and fewer blooms. Ideally, place it near a south or west-facing window where it can enjoy filtered light. If growing outdoors, ensure it is in a location where it receives partial shade, protected from the harshest midday sun, to thrive best."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Justicia aurea involves removing spent flowers and trimming back leggy or overgrown stems to maintain its shape and encourage bushy growth. It's best to prune this plant after its blooming period to avoid removing potential flowers. Cutting back the plant by a third in early spring can promote robust growth. Also, remove any dead or yellowing leaves to improve air circulation and reduce the risk of disease. Regularly pinching back the tips of the branches can also help in promoting a fuller, more compact plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Yellow Jacobinia","description":"Justicia umbrosa (Brazilian plume, yellow jacobinia; syn. Adhatoda umbrosa Ness, and Justicia aurea Schltdl.) is an ornamental shrub native of Cerrado vegetation of Brazil. This plant may be propagated by herbaceous stem cutting, and it can usually get to 1,50 - 2,50 m tall. They flourish in the shade, and will not do well if overwatered.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":["Yellow Jacobinia"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Justicia aurea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17656,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lobelia nuttallii, commonly known as Nuttall's lobelia, prefers consistently moist soil conditions. It is essential to water this plant regularly to maintain evenly moist soil, especially during dry periods. While it can tolerate brief dry spells, allowing the soil to dry out completely can lead to stress and affect its growth. To avoid waterlogging, ensure well-draining soil. A layer of mulch can help retain moisture and regulate soil temperature, which is beneficial during hotter months. Adjust watering frequency depending on rainfall and temperature changes throughout the growing season."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lobelia nuttallii thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and flowering. In regions with intense midday sun, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to protect the plant from scorching. Inadequate sunlight may result in reduced flowering and leggy growth. Choosing a planting location that provides morning sun and afternoon shade can balance this requirement, especially in hotter climates. Adjust the light conditions based on the plant’s growth response to ensure it remains healthy and vigorous."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lobelia nuttallii involves removing spent flowers and any dead or damaged stems to promote healthy growth. Deadheading, or cutting back the faded blooms, encourages the plant to produce more flowers and extend the blooming period. Performing a light prune at the end of the flowering season helps maintain a tidy appearance and can prevent the plant from becoming too leggy. It is best to use clean, sharp pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant. Avoid excessive pruning, as this can stress the plant and impact its vitality."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Nuttall's Lobelia","description":"Lobelia nuttallii is a species of flowering plant in the bellflower family commonly called Nuttall's lobelia. It is native to the Eastern United States where it is found in coastal areas, with disjunct populations in the Southern Blue Ridge Mountains and the Cumberland Plateau. It is mostly found in habitats with wet, sandy, acidic soils such as flatwoods and southern bogs.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Nuttall's Lobelia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Lobelia nuttallii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

To care for it properly, water the plant regularly during its growing season (spring and summer) to keep the soil lightly moist, but be sure to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. Reduce watering in the fall and winter when the plant is not actively growing, letting the soil dry out more between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hedysarum alpinum thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day, which supports healthy growth and flowering. If grown in areas with strong afternoon sun, providing some shade during peak hours can help prevent leaf scorch. In regions with very hot climates, morning sun and afternoon shade are preferred. Avoid heavy pruning or cutting back the plant too severely, as this may stress the plant or inhibit flowering. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to prevent the spread of diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Alpine Sweet-vetch","description":"Hedysarum alpinum is a species of flowering plant in the legume family known by the common name alpine sweetvetch. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16862,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Polygala vulgaris, commonly known as common milkwort, prefers a moderate watering schedule. It thrives in well-drained soil and is somewhat drought-tolerant once established. During the growing season, water regularly to keep the soil lightly moist, but be careful to avoid waterlogging. Allow the top layer of soil to dry out between waterings. In winter, when the plant is dormant, reduce watering significantly, providing just enough moisture to prevent the soil from completely drying out. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so it's essential to find a balance and adjust based on weather conditions and soil drainage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Polygala vulgaris thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. It is best grown in a location where it can get at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to promote abundant flowering. However, in areas with intense afternoon sun, some light shading can protect the plant from excessive heat. Partial shade, particularly in hotter climates, may help prevent the plant from drying out too quickly. When choosing a planting site, ensure it provides adequate sun exposure while also allowing for some respite during the hottest parts of the day to keep the plant healthy and vibrant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Polygala vulgaris is usually minimal. To promote a neat appearance and encourage bushy growth, you can lightly trim the plant after it finishes flowering. Remove any dead or damaged stems throughout the growing season to maintain its health. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17161,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vitex negundo prefers well-drained soil and is relatively drought-tolerant, making it well-suited to areas with irregular rainfall. Water the plant regularly during its initial growth phase to establish a strong root system. Once established, Vitex negundo can tolerate dry conditions but will benefit from occasional deep watering, especially during prolonged dry spells. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot; therefore, it's ideal to let the soil dry out between watering sessions. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering required."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vitex negundo thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and flowering, plant it in a location where it receives at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate some degree of shade, too little sunlight may result in reduced blooming and a leggy appearance. In regions with extremely hot temperatures, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch and stress. The key is balancing enough sunlight to encourage vigorous blooms while shielding it from the harshest sunlight conditions if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vitex negundo is essential to encourage bushy growth and maintain its desired shape. It is best pruned in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and overall plant health. Regularly cutting back the plant can encourage robust flowering as well. For more controlled growth, lightly prune after each flowering cycle to prevent it from becoming too leggy. Be sure not to prune too late in the year, as this plant blooms on new wood, meaning late pruning could affect the upcoming flower cycle."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Five-leaved chaste tree","description":"Vitex negundo, commonly known as the Chinese chastetree, five-leaved chaste tree, or horseshoe vitex, is a large aromatic shrub with quadrangular, densely whitish, tomentose branchlets. If grown indoors, place it near a bright, south-facing window where it can receive plenty of light. The best time for pruning is in late winter or early spring before the growing season begins. Cut back overgrown or tangled vines to maintain a desired shape and size. Pruning also stimulates flower production by allowing more light and air to reach the inner parts of the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"banana passionfruit","description":"Banana passionfruit is the fruit of several plants in the genus Passiflora, and is therefore related to the passion fruit. If natural sunlight is insufficient indoors, supplement with fluorescent grow lights to provide the necessary light spectrum for healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Diplotaxis erucoides is relatively straightforward and should focus on maintaining its shape and encouraging healthy growth. Additionally, to promote bushier growth, pinch back the tips of the plant periodically. This encourages the plant to grow laterally rather than vertically. During the flowering season, deadheading spent flowers can also prolong blooming and maintain the plant's aesthetic appeal. Always perform pruning in the early morning or late afternoon to avoid plant stress."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"White Wall-rocket","description":"Diplotaxis erucoides, the white rocket or white wallrocket, is a species of annual herb of the family Brassicaceae native to West Mediterranean.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean region"],"other_name":["White Wall-rocket"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Diplotaxis erucoides"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16175,"attracts":["Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Celtis pallida, commonly known as desert hackberry, is a drought-tolerant plant well-suited to arid environments. When it comes to watering, it requires minimal irrigation, especially once established. Initially, during its first growing season, it is beneficial to water the plant regularly to help establish its root system. After this period, reduce watering significantly. It thrives in dry, well-drained soils and excessive watering can lead to root rot. Therefore, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings is recommended. This plant is resilient and can survive on rainfall alone in many cases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Celtis pallida thrives best in full sun, which means it requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. It is well adapted to hot and arid climates, making it perfect for planting in areas that receive intense, unfiltered sunlight. This plant also demonstrates a remarkable capacity to withstand high temperatures and UV radiation. While it can tolerate some degree of partial shade, optimal growth occurs when it's exposed to bright, sunny conditions. Providing adequate sunlight ensures robust growth, healthy foliage, and optimal flowering and berry production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Celtis pallida should be done sparingly and primarily for maintenance purposes. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Focus on removing any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and maintain the plant's shape. It's also advisable to cut back branches that are overgrowing their space or interfering with nearby structures. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the plant. It is crucial not to let the soil dry out completely, especially during hot summer months. Water the plant thoroughly when the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch. It is important to avoid waterlogging, as the plant does not tolerate excessive wetness well. During periods of active growth in the spring and summer, increase water frequency, and reduce it during the dormant winter period. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency needed for watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Helenium elegans thrives best in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. The plant tends to develop taller and less sturdy stems in partial shade, which can lead to flopping. When planted in a sunny location, it develops vibrant flowers and maintains a more compact and upright growth habit. Ensure the planting site provides adequate airflow and avoid overly crowded areas to reduce the risk of fungal diseases commonly occurring in overly damp and shaded conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Helenium elegans encourages bushier growth and enhances flowering. In early spring, cut back last year's growth to about 6 inches above the ground to tidy up the plant and prepare it for the new season. Throughout its growing season, deadhead spent flowers to prolong the blooming period and promote additional flowering. In late autumn, after the plant has finished flowering, you may cut the plant back to the ground if in a region with harsh winters, or leave stems standing for winter interest and wildlife shelter, and then prune in early spring."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pretty Sneezeweed","description":"Helenium elegans is a North American perennial plant in the sunflower family, commonly known as pretty sneezeweed. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17361,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Coprosma foetidissima prefers consistently moist soil but should not be waterlogged. Water the plant regularly, especially during dry periods, ensuring the top few inches of soil do not dry out completely. It's important to balance moisture, as too much water can lead to root rot, while too little causes stress. If planted in a container, ensure good drainage by using a pot with holes and a well-draining soil mix. Be sure to adjust watering based on the plant's growing conditions: more frequent watering might be necessary in hotter climates, less in cooler."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Coprosma foetidissima thrives in partial to full shade conditions, making it ideal for shaded areas in gardens. It adapts well to dappled sunlight but should be protected from intense, direct sunlight, particularly in hotter climates, as this can scorch its leaves. If grown indoors, place it near a window where it receives bright, indirect light. Ensure the plant does not experience excessive shade, which could stunt its growth. Balancing light conditions is key to maintaining healthy foliage and encouraging robust growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Coprosma foetidissima generally involves shaping the plant and removing any dead or damaged branches. Pruning is best done in late winter to early spring, before new growth begins. Regular light pruning can help maintain a desired shape and encourage bushier growth. Remove any parts of the plant that look unhealthy to prevent the spread of disease. For more formal shaping, trim back growth to an outward-pointing bud to encourage branching. Remember not to over-prune, as this can stress the plant and inhibit growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hūpiro","description":"Coprosma foetidissima, commonly known as stinkwood or hūpiro, is a shrub native to New Zealand.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Purple\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Hūpiro"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Coprosma foetidissima"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's best to water this cactus deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. During the active growing season (spring and summer), water approximately every two to three weeks. In fall and winter, when the plant is dormant, reduce watering to once a month or even less if the environment is humid. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the pot has adequate drainage and avoid letting the cactus sit in water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ferocactus robustus thrives in bright, direct sunlight, making it well-suited to a sunny windowsill or outdoor location with full sun exposure. Ideally, the cactus should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. In hot climates, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent sunburn. If growing indoors, place it in a south-facing window, ensuring it's not obstructed by curtains or other objects. Gradually acclimate new plants to full sun to prevent sudden sunburn. Adequate sunlight helps in maintaining the cactus's robust structure and vibrant coloration."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ferocactus robustus is usually minimal and primarily involves removing dead or diseased parts. Since this cactus naturally maintains its shape, regular pruning isn't necessary. When removing parts of the plant, use clean, sharp tools to avoid infection. If you remove offsets or pups for propagation, ensure they have calloused over before replanting. Avoid excessive handling of the cactus, as its spines can be quite sharp. Regularly inspect for pests or rot, and remove any affected areas promptly to maintain plant health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":"Ferocactus robustus is a barrel cactus in the genus Ferocactus belonging to the family Cacteae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":["Cochineal insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Ferocactus robustus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17657,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Nephroma arcticum, commonly known as the \"tree lungwort\" or \"arctic kidney lichen,\" requires minimal watering when grown in a controlled environment, as it primarily derives its moisture from the air. In cultivation, it should be misted lightly rather than soaked, ensuring that it remains in a humid environment to mimic its natural conditions. Overwatering can lead to fungal issues or decay, so it is crucial to allow the substrate it sits on to dry out slightly between misting. Typically, misting once or twice a week is sufficient depending on the ambient humidity levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Nephroma arcticum prefers indirect light, as direct sunlight can be too harsh and cause desiccation of the lichen. Ideally, it should be placed in an area where it receives dappled light or bright indirect sunlight, such as near a north or east-facing window. Too little light may hinder its growth, so a balance is needed to provide the right amount of ambient, indirect illumination. If necessary, artificial grow lights can be used to supplement natural light, but they should be set to mimic the length and intensity of natural daylight conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Nephroma arcticum is generally unnecessary as it naturally maintains its shape and size. However, any dead or damaged parts of the lichen can be gently removed to allow for healthy growth and better air circulation. Pruning should be done carefully by hand to avoid disturbing the relatively fragile structure of the lichen. Regularly inspecting the lichen for any signs of disease or decay can help maintain its health, and any pruning should be done using sterilized instruments to prevent contamination."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Arctic Kidney Lichen","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Gray-green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Arctic","Boreal regions across the Northern Hemisphere"],"other_name":["Arctic Kidney Lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Nephroma arcticum"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun encourages its best growth performance and helps the tree develop a strong structure. It is important to avoid locations with heavy shade, as insufficient light can lead to sparse growth and weakened branches. Ideally planted in an open space, this tree will flourish with ample sun throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Cupressus forbesii minimally to maintain its natural form and health. Pruning is generally not required except to remove dead, diseased, or crossing branches. Late winter to early spring is the best time for pruning, before new growth starts. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16564,"attracts":["Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Justicia spicigera, commonly known as Mexican Honeysuckle, prefers regular watering to thrive. The plant should be watered deeply once a week, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings. In hotter conditions or during active growth seasons like spring and summer, you may need to increase frequency to twice a week, especially if the plant is in a pot or sandy soil that drains quickly. Avoid waterlogging as it can lead to root rot. Using well-drained soil will help prevent this issue, ensuring that excess water can escape easily."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Justicia spicigera thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. The plant can also grow well in partial shade, making it a versatile option for various garden spots. However, to encourage optimal flowering, providing full sun exposure for at least 4-6 hours a day can be beneficial. In extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent the foliage from scorching. Indoors, place the plant near a south-facing window to ensure adequate light, and consider supplementing with artificial grow lights if natural light is insufficient."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Justicia spicigera can help encourage bushier growth and maintain a desired shape. It is best to prune in early spring before the new growth begins, using clean, sharp pruning shears. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems first, followed by any crossing branches that may affect air circulation. You can also trim back straggly stems to keep the plant tidy and compact. Light pruning can be done throughout the growing season, but avoid heavy cutting in late fall, as it may stress the plant before winter."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Mexican Honeysuckle","description":"Justicia spicigera (Mexican honeysuckle, firecracker bush, moyotle, moyotli, mohintli, muicle, trompetilla, or ych-kaan in Mayan) is an evergreen shrub with tubular orange flowers. The species is native to Belize, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Mexico and Nicaragua. It has been used as a traditional medicine for the treatment of dysentery, heart problems, asthma and a number of other ailments. Like other traditional medicines, these claims cannot be substantiated by research.","family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":["Mexican Honeysuckle"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Justicia spicigera"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If grown in too much shade, the plant may become spindly and have reduced flowering, so finding a sunny spot is key for its success."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Crocanthemum canadense involves removing spent flowers to encourage additional blooming and maintain the plant's appearance. Pruning can be done lightly throughout the growing season to remove dead or damaged growth. After the flowering season, cut back the plant to remove old stems and promote vigorous new growth for the next season. This will also help maintain a tidy appearance and prevent the plant from becoming too woody. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to make precise cuts and minimize damage to the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Canada frostweed","description":"Helianthemum canadense or Crocanthemum canadense (known as longbranch frostweed, Canada frostweed, frostweed, rock frost, frostplant, or frostwort) is a species of rock-rose (Cistaceae), native to eastern North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Canada frostweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Crocanthemum canadense"],"soil":["Dry","Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17163,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Watsonia borbonica preferably requires a moderate watering schedule. Ensure the soil is kept consistently moist during its active growing season, which is typically in spring and summer. However, it is crucial to avoid overwatering; the soil should not become waterlogged as this can lead to root rot. Allow the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. During its dormant phase, you can reduce the frequency of watering, keeping the soil drier, but not completely dry, to prevent the corms from drying out."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Watsonia borbonica thrives best in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of sunlight per day. Planting it in an area with ample sunlight is crucial for its optimal growth and flowering. Although it can tolerate partial shade, blooming may be less prolific. In hotter climates, providing a little shade during the peak afternoon sunlight can help prevent leaf scorch. If grown indoors or in partial-sun environments, consider supplementing it with grow lights to ensure it receives adequate light, promoting healthy development and vibrant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Watsonia borbonica is generally straightforward. After the flowering period, which occurs in late spring to early summer, it's recommended to deadhead the plant by removing the spent flower spikes. This prevents the plant from putting energy into seed production and encourages healthier growth. Additionally, as the leaves begin to die back naturally, they can be trimmed away to maintain a tidy appearance. Avoid cutting back green foliage as the plant uses these leaves for photosynthesis and energy storage. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bugle-lily","description":"Watsonia borbonica, the Cape bugle-lily, is a species of plant in the family Iridaceae that is native to South Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Bugle-lily"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Watsonia borbonica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16176,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Centaurea nigrescens does not require frequent watering and prefers well-drained soil. Water the plant deeply but allow the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. In periods of prolonged drought, it may require more frequent watering, but generally, it is quite drought-tolerant once established. Always check the top few inches of soil to ensure it has dried out before watering again."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Centaurea nigrescens thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. For optimal growth and flowering, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. If planted in partial shade, ensure that it still gets a few hours of sunlight, preferably in the morning. While it can tolerate some shade, reduced sunlight may lead to fewer blooms and leggier growth. Planting in full sun will help achieve a robust and floriferous display."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Centaurea nigrescens helps maintain its shape and encourages healthy growth. Deadhead spent flowers regularly to prevent self-seeding and to promote prolonged blooming. Cutting back the plant by about one-third after the flowering season can help rejuvenate it and promote denser growth. Any browned or dead foliage should be removed to enhance appearance and reduce the risk of pest infestations. Pruning also encourages a tidier look in the garden and can control its spread in a flower bed."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Tyrol knapweed","description":"Centaurea nigrescens (Tyrol knapweed, short-fringed knapweed or Tyrol thistle) is a perennial plant of the star thistle genus that grows natively in Central and South-eastern Europe (from Southern Germany and Northern Italy to Romania and Bulgaria), but has also been introduced and is now a noxious weed in the Northern United States, Canada and Southern Australia. It has purple flowers and it flowers in the summer (June to September).","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Tyrol knapweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Centaurea nigrescens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17362,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Coprosma lucida prefers well-drained soil that stays evenly moist. It is important to water this plant regularly, especially during dry spells. However, be careful not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. Allow the soil to slightly dry out between waterings. During the growing season, which is typically spring and summer, increase watering frequency, and reduce it during the fall and winter months when the plant's growth slows. Ensure that there is good drainage in the pot or garden bed to prevent waterlogging and maintain healthy root systems."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Coprosma lucida thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and vibrant foliage color. In areas with harsh afternoon sunlight, it may benefit from some shade to prevent leaf scorching. While it can tolerate partial shade, too little light can cause the plant to become leggy and reduce its overall vibrancy. When growing indoors, place it in a bright room with plenty of indirect light, such as near a south or west-facing window, to maintain its health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Coprosma lucida is beneficial for maintaining its shape and encouraging healthy growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Remove any dead or damaged branches to improve air circulation and reduce the risk of diseases. You can also trim back any overgrown or leggy branches to maintain the plant's desired shape and size. Be sure to use clean, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts and avoid unnecessary damage to the plant. Regular pruning will also promote a bushier and more compact appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Shining Karamu","description":"Coprosma lucida, commonly known in Māori as karamū, and also known as shiny karamu, is a shrub native to New Zealand. The shrub is found throughout the North and South Island.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Shining Karamu"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Coprosma lucida"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It should not be watered directly like a terrestrial plant, but instead, the surrounding environment should be kept humid enough to prevent it from drying out. If grown indoors or in a container, ensure that it receives indirect moisture, such as through misting or by placing it in a terrarium where humidity levels are consistently high. Overwatering can lead to issues, so it’s best to let the ambient moisture do the work."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pannaria conoplea typically grows in shaded or partially shaded environments where it receives filtered sunlight. It thrives in dappled light conditions commonly found on tree trunks or shaded rock faces. Direct sunlight should be avoided as it can lead to desiccation or bleaching of the thallus. If cultivated in an artificial or indoor setting, it should be placed in a location where it can receive indirect natural light or supplemented with artificial light that mimics the low-intensity light conditions of its natural habitat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Pannaria conoplea is minimal to none due to its lichen nature. Typically, lichens do not require pruning as they naturally grow in their unique, crustose or leaf-like forms depending on the substrate they are on. However, if necessary, you can gently remove any dead or unsightly parts with careful precision using a sharp tool to avoid damaging the lichen’s main body. Any pruning should focus on enhancing its appearance or removing decayed areas, supporting healthier growth overall."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mealy-rimmed Shingle Lichen","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Gray-green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","North America"],"other_name":["Mealy-rimmed Shingle Lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Pannaria conoplea"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16865,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Portulaca grandiflora, commonly known as moss rose, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering. It thrives in dry conditions, so allowing the soil to dry out between waterings is recommended. During hot summer months, water once a week if you notice the soil completely drying out. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. This plant grows well in sandy, well-draining soil, which helps prevent water from pooling around the roots. Ensure the pot or garden bed provides good drainage to keep the plant healthy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Portulaca grandiflora loves full sun and requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily to thrive. This plant is highly sun-tolerant and performs best when exposed to bright, direct sunlight. If grown indoors, placing it near a window with full sun exposure is ideal. Inadequate sunlight can lead to reduced blooming and stretched, leggy growth. Outdoors, ensure it's planted in a location that receives uninterrupted sunlight throughout the day to maximize its vibrant flowering display."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Portulaca grandiflora is relatively simple and helps promote healthy growth and blooms. Regularly deadhead spent flowers to encourage the plant to produce more blooms. You can also pinch back leggy stems to maintain a compact shape and encourage bushier growth. Pruning should be done with clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant. It is particularly beneficial to prune back any damaged or discolored leaves or stem portions, especially after blooming, to rejuvenate the plant for the next growing season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"moss-rose purslane","description":"Portulaca grandiflora, (Urdu: گل دوپہری‎)(Bengali: টাইম ফুল) is a succulent flowering plant in the family Portulacaceae, native to Argentina, southern Brazil, and Uruguay and often cultivated in gardens. It has many common names, including rose moss, ten o'clock, Mexican rose, moss rose, Vietnam Rose, sun rose, rock rose, and moss-rose purslane.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink, Yellow, Orange, Red, White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["moss-rose purslane"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Portulaca grandiflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16960,"attracts":["Bees","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salvia greggii, commonly known as autumn sage, prefers dry to medium moisture conditions. It is drought-tolerant once established, but regular watering will support best growth and flowering. During the growing season, water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between watering sessions. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot or other fungal issues. In the winter, reduce watering as the plant enters a period of dormancy. It's important to ensure good drainage to prevent water from pooling around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salvia greggii thrives in full sun conditions, needing at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to produce abundant flowers and maintain vigorous growth. While it can tolerate partial shade, blooming might be reduced, and the plant may become leggy. In very hot climates, a location with some light afternoon shade can help protect it from intense mid-day sun and prolong the flowering period. Ensuring the plant enjoys a position with plenty of sunlight will help it maintain a compact, bushy shape and support healthy flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salvia greggii is beneficial to promote bushier growth and to extend the blooming period. Typically, pruning should be done in early spring before new growth begins. Trim back the previous year’s growth, reducing stems by about a third to maintain shape and encourage new growth. Throughout the growing season, deadhead spent flowers to encourage the plant to continue blooming. A light pruning in late summer can also rejuvenate the plant for additional blooms into the fall. The plant's vibrant flowers open under sunny conditions and may close during overcast weather or at night. Avoid placing it in shaded areas, as insufficient light can lead to reduced flowering and leggy growth. If growing indoors, consider a sunny window or supplementing with a grow light if natural light is limited."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Portulaca umbraticola is a straightforward process that helps maintain its compact shape and encourages fuller growth. The best time to prune is during the growing season, typically spring and summer. Remove any dead or yellowing leaves to promote healthy new growth. Additionally, you can pinch back overgrown stems to encourage a bushier appearance. For plants that become leggy or sparse, more aggressive trimming may be necessary to rejuvenate the plant's appearance. Always use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to prevent damage to the plant and reduce the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"wingpod purslane","description":"Portulaca umbraticola, also known as the wingpod purslane, is a perennial succulent in the genus of flowering plants 'Portulaca.'","family":null,"flower_color":"Red, Orange, Yellow, White, Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["wingpod purslane"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Portulaca umbraticola"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16566,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Kalanchoe daigremontiana, commonly known as the Mother of Thousands, requires careful watering. It is a succulent, so it stores water in its leaves and prefers dry conditions. Water the plant thoroughly when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. It's crucial not to overwater, as soggy soil can lead to root rot. During winter months, reduce watering frequency since the plant's growth slows down and it requires less moisture. Always ensure proper drainage and avoid letting the plant sit in standing water to maintain healthy roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Kalanchoe daigremontiana thrives with plenty of bright, indirect sunlight. Ideally, place the plant in a location where it receives around 6-8 hours of filtered sunlight each day. Direct sunlight exposure, especially during the intense midday hours, should be avoided as it can cause leaf burn. A south or east-facing window is generally ideal. If natural light is insufficient, especially in winter, supplement with artificial grow lights to maintain healthy growth. Regularly rotate the plant to ensure even exposure and prevent leaning towards the light source."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Kalanchoe daigremontiana involves removing any dead or damaged leaves and stems to encourage healthy growth. Additionally, trimming back leggy or excessively long branches can help maintain a compact shape. Use clean and sharp pruning shears to prevent any damage or spread of disease. After flowering, remove spent blooms to keep the plant tidy and encourage new growth. Regular pruning not only enhances the plant's appearance but also promotes more robust growth. Be cautious of the plant’s tiny plantlets, which can root wherever they fall, possibly becoming invasive."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Alligator Plant","description":"Bryophyllum daigremontianum, commonly called devil’s backbone, mother of thousands, alligator plant, or Mexican hat plant is a succulent plant native to Madagascar. Like other members of its genus Bryophyllum, it is able to propagate vegetatively from plantlets that develop on its phylloclade margins. All parts of the plant contain a very toxic steroid known as daigremontianin.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Madagascar"],"other_name":["Alligator Plant"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Kalanchoe daigremontiana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of full sunlight every day for optimal growth and flowering. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent the leaves from scorching. Though it is adaptable to shading conditions, too much shade can lead to sparse flowering and leggy growth. Ensuring it receives adequate sunlight will promote healthier foliage and a more robust plant overall. Observing the plant's response to light and adjusting its exposure accordingly can enhance its growth and flowering potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Fallopia scandens is essential to maintain its shape and control its growth. It is typically pruned in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. You can remove any dead or damaged stems and cut back overly vigorous growth to encourage a more bushy appearance. Regular pruning can prevent the plant from becoming too invasive, as it can spread quickly. Trimming back a third of the growth can stimulate healthy new shoots. It's also beneficial to remove tangled or crossing branches to improve air circulation and light penetration within the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"climbing false buckwheat","description":"Fallopia scandens (climbing false buckwheat) is a species of Fallopia native to North America. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17165,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Wisteria floribunda, commonly known as Japanese wisteria, requires moderate watering. It is important to keep the soil consistently moist, especially during its first growing season, to establish a strong root system. However, avoid over-watering as it can lead to root rot. Once established, wisteria is fairly drought-tolerant, but it will bloom more profusely with regular watering. Aim to water deeply once a week during dry periods, ensuring the water reaches deep into the root zone, but allow the top inch of soil to dry out between watering sessions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Wisteria floribunda thrives in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal blooming. While it can tolerate partial shade, its flowering may be significantly reduced. A sunny south or west-facing spot is ideal to ensure the plant receives ample sunlight. If possible, provide exposure to morning sun to help dry off foliage early in the day, reducing the likelihood of diseases. Adequate sunlight encourages robust growth and an abundant display of its beautiful, cascading flowers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is crucial for maintaining the shape and encouraging the blooms of Wisteria floribunda. Prune twice a year: once in late winter and again in the summer. In winter, cut back lateral shoots to 2-3 buds to encourage flower production. Summer pruning involves trimming the long shoots from the current year’s growth back to about six inches, promoting a tidy appearance and future flowering. Regular pruning controls the plant's vigorous growth, prevents it from becoming unmanageable, and helps to enhance the flowering potential."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Japanese wisteria","description":"Wisteria floribunda (common name Japanese wisteria) is a species of flowering plant in the pea family Fabaceae, native to Japan. Growing to 9 m (30 ft), it is a woody, deciduous twining climber. It was brought from Japan to the United States in 1830's. Since then, it has become one of the most highly romanticized flowering garden plants. It is also a common subject for bonsai, along with Wisteria sinensis (Chinese wisteria).","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Japan"],"other_name":["Japanese wisteria"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation","Layering Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Wisteria floribunda"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Pruning in early spring is ideal as it helps the plant direct energy to new growth. During hot and dry periods, more frequent watering may be necessary. Water at the base of the plant in the morning to keep the foliage dry and minimize the risk of fungal diseases. In container gardens, they may need more frequent watering as potted soil dries out more quickly than ground soil."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Zinnia elegans thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. This practice encourages more blooms and extends the flowering season. To deadhead, cut back each stem to just above a set of leaves or a side branch. Additionally, if the plants become leggy or overgrown, they can be cut back by about one-third of their height to promote bushier growth. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16961,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salvia microphylla, commonly known as baby sage, requires well-drained soil and should be watered moderately. It's important to allow the soil to dry out between watering to prevent root rot. During the growing season, typically spring through fall, water the plant when the top inch of the soil feels dry. In winter, reduce the frequency as the plant’s growth slows down. Overwatering can be detrimental, so always ensure the plant is not sitting in water. Mulching can help retain moisture but make sure it's done carefully to not keep the soil too moist."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salvia microphylla thrives in full sun but can tolerate partial shade. For optimal growth and blooming, ensure the plant receives at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade will help prevent leaf scorch and maintain vibrant foliage. If grown in partial shade, expect potentially fewer blooms. It's essential to monitor the plant's exposure, especially in areas with very intense sunlight, as too much direct sun without adequate water might stress the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salvia microphylla promotes bushier growth and more blooms. The best time to prune is in early spring before new growth starts. Cut back the previous year's growth by about one-third to one-half, focusing on removing any dead or damaged stems. During the growing season, deadhead spent flowers to encourage continuous blooming. Lightly trim back after flowering if necessary to maintain shape. Additionally, in late fall, remove any diseased or crossing branches to prevent overcrowding and to maintain the health of the plant through winter."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Baby Sage","description":"Salvia microphylla (Baby sage, Graham's sage, Blackcurrant sage) is a perennial shrub found in the wild in southeastern Arizona and the mountains of eastern, western, and southern Mexico. It is a very complex species which easily hybridizes, resulting in numerous hybrids and cultivars brought into horticulture since the 1990s. The specific epithet microphylla, from the Greek, means \"small leaved\". In Mexico, it is called \"mirto de montes,\" or \"myrtle of the mountains.\"","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["Baby Sage"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Salvia microphylla"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid letting the water become stagnant, as good water circulation promotes health and growth in aquatic plants like Potamogeton perfoliatus."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Potamogeton perfoliatus, also known as clasping-leaf pondweed, thrives in full to partial sunlight conditions. Ideally, this aquatic plant needs about 6-8 hours of light each day, either from natural sunlight or artificial grow lights, if kept indoors. If grown in an outdoor pond, ensure it receives enough sunlight without being entirely shaded by taller structures or plants. However, be cautious of excessive heat and direct sun exposure in hotter climates, which could increase water temperature and affect plant health. Balance is key to ensuring optimal growth and health for Potamogeton perfoliatus."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Potamogeton perfoliatus involves trimming the plant to manage its size and promote healthier growth. As an aquatic plant, it can become overgrown, making occasional pruning necessary to prevent it from overtaking your pond or aquarium. Use scissors or an aquatic plant trimmer to remove any dead, damaged, or excess stems. This should be done during its growing season, typically spring to early fall. Regular pruning also helps increase light penetration and water flow, which are vital for the plant's overall health and the well-being of its aquatic environment."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Perfoliate Pondweed","description":"Potamogeton perfoliatus (claspingleaf pondweed, perfoliate pondweed, redhead grass) is a perennial aquatic plant in the family Potamogetonaceae occurring in both standing and flowing freshwater habitats. Adjusting the plant's position according to seasonal changes in sunlight can be beneficial."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Kalmia hirsuta should be minimal and mainly focused on maintaining its shape and health. The best time to prune is shortly after it has finished flowering. Remove any dead or damaged branches first. You can also lightly trim the plant to encourage bushier growth and maintain a desired shape. Avoid heavy pruning, especially during the late summer or fall, as this might reduce flowering in the next season. Regularly removing spent flowers can promote a tidier appearance and healthier growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sandhill laurel","description":"Kalmia hirsuta, the hairy mountain-laurel, is a plant species native to the southeastern United States. During the first growing season, water the plant regularly until it is well established. Once established, water sparingly, only during prolonged dry periods. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other moisture-related issues as Eryngium prefers dry, well-drained soil conditions. It's important to let the soil dry out between waterings. During the winter months, reduce watering significantly as the plant is dormant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eryngium campestre thrives in full sun and requires at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to grow optimally. Additionally, ample sunlight helps in preventing the soil from retaining too much moisture, which can be detrimental to this drought-resistant plant. If growing indoors or in a less sunny area, consider supplementing with grow lights to mimic its natural sun exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Eryngium campestre is generally done to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. Remove any dead or damaged leaves throughout the year as they appear. Deadheading, or removing spent blooms, can prolong the blooming period and prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively. In late autumn or early winter, after the plant has finished blooming, cut back the stems to ground level to prepare it for the next growing season. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to prevent the spread of disease. Be careful with the spiny leaves and wear gloves when handling."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Field Eryngo","description":"Eryngium campestre, known as field eryngo, is a species of Eryngium, which is used medicinally. A member of the Apiaceae family, Eryngo is a hairless, thorny perennial. The leaves are tough and stiff, whitish-green. The basal leaves are long-stalked, pinnate and spiny. The leaves of this plant are mined by the gall fly which is called Euleia heraclei.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Western Asia"],"other_name":["Field Eryngo"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Eryngium campestre"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It should be watered deeply but infrequently to encourage the growth of a robust root system. Allow the soil to dry out between waterings, especially in areas with high humidity. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to ensure that the plant is not sitting in waterlogged soil. During periods of drought, these plants can survive on minimal water, but they will thrive with a bit of supplementary watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Helianthus occidentalis thrives in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day. This exposure is crucial for optimal flowering and growth. In partial shade, the plant can survive but may exhibit leggier growth and reduced flowering. It's well-suited for prairie gardens, open meadows, or any landscape setting that offers unobstructed sunlight. For best results, plant in a location that captures full morning sun, as this helps prevent mildew and other fungal diseases that can occur in too-shady conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Helianthus occidentalis is generally minimal, as this plant often maintains a tidy appearance on its own. However, deadheading, or the removal of spent blooms, can promote continued flowering throughout the growing season and prevent the plant from going to seed too early. At the end of the growing season, it's beneficial to cut back the stems to about six inches from the ground once they've turned brown, which helps rejuvenate the plant for the next year. Regularly removing dead or damaged foliage also keeps the plant looking its best."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"fewleaf sunflower","description":"Helianthus occidentalis (fewleaf sunflower or western sunflower) is a species of sunflower native to the Eastern and Central United States. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17261,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"The Symphytum × uplandicum, commonly known as Russian Comfrey, requires regular watering to keep the soil consistently moist, particularly during dry spells. It thrives in well-draining soil but can tolerate less ideal conditions once established. Be cautious not to overwater as excessively soggy soil can lead to root rot. It is beneficial to mulch around the base of the plant to retain soil moisture and regulate temperature. During the active growing season in spring and summer, more frequent watering is necessary, while in the dormant winter months, it can be reduced substantially."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Symphytum × uplandicum thrives in full sun to partial shade, making it a versatile plant for different garden settings. It performs best in an area where it receives at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to promote robust growth and flowering. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent the leaves from scorching and the soil from drying out too quickly. If grown in more shaded conditions, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers, so balance is key for optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Symphytum × uplandicum is mostly minimal but beneficial to encourage healthy growth and manage size. During late spring or early summer, you should cut back any flowering stems once the flowers have finished blooming to encourage a second flush of growth and prevent unwanted seeding. At the end of the growing season, in late fall, cut the plant back to ground level to tidy up and promote fresh growth in spring. Using sharp, clean tools will help prevent disease, and timely removal of any damaged leaves helps maintain plant health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Russian Comfrey","description":"Symphytum is a genus of flowering plants in the borage family, Boraginaceae. There are up to 35 species, known by the common name comfrey (pronounced /ˈkʌmfri/). Some species and hybrids, particularly S. officinale and S. × uplandicum, are used in gardening and herbal medicine. They are not to be confused with Andersonglossum virginianum, known as wild comfrey, another member of the borage family.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Russian Comfrey"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Symphytum × uplandicum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It can tolerate dappled sunlight or a few hours of morning sun, but too much direct sunlight can lead to scorched leaves. In areas with hot summers, ensure it's planted in a location that provides afternoon shade. Despite being shade-tolerant, the plant will benefit from some light exposure, aiding in plentiful and vibrant foliage growth. If growing indoors, place it near a north or east-facing window for optimal light conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Yellowroot requires minimal pruning, but occasional maintenance can help keep the plant tidy and healthy. Prune away any dead or damaged stems throughout the growing season to maintain appearance and prevent disease. Additionally, thinning out crowded areas can improve air circulation, reducing the risk of fungal issues. In early spring, before new growth appears, you can cut back older stems to the ground to encourage new, vigorous shoots. Since yellowroot spreads via rhizomes, managing its spread by removing excess shoots may also be necessary if it begins to encroach on other garden areas."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Shrub Yellowroot","description":"Xanthorhiza simplicissima (yellowroot) is the only member of the genus Xanthorhiza, and one of very few genera in the family Ranunculaceae with a woody stem (the other notable example being Clematis). It contains the alkaloid berberine, which has a number of traditional and contemporary uses for dyeing and medicine.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Shrub Yellowroot"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf spot","Root rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Xanthorhiza simplicissima"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

To properly care for this plant, it is crucial to maintain a balance in moisture levels. Ensure that the soil remains consistently damp but not waterlogged, as excess water can lead to root rot. It is advisable to water the plant whenever the top layer of soil begins to dry. During hot weather, more frequent watering may be necessary to prevent the soil from drying out. Implementing a well-draining soil mix will also help prevent water from accumulating excessively around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phyllachne colensoi prefers environments that provide partial to full sunlight exposure, similar to its native alpine habitats. For optimal growth, this cushion plant should be placed in a location that receives bright, indirect sunlight most of the day. Direct sunlight during the hottest part of the day can be too intense, so providing some afternoon shade may be necessary to prevent scorching, particularly in warm climates. If grown indoors, placing the plant near a north or east-facing window will typically offer an ideal balance of light. Adjust lighting conditions as needed to mimic these preferences."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phyllachne colensoi is generally minimal due to its cushion-like growth form. However, to ensure healthy growth and maintain its compact shape, occasional pruning can be beneficial. During the first growing season, regular watering helps the plant develop a strong root system, but once mature, it can endure prolonged dry periods. When choosing a planting site, consider open areas like gardens or meadows, where the plant can receive uninterrupted sunlight. Overall, ensuring plenty of sunlight is crucial for its optimal health and flower production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Thelesperma filifolium involves removing spent blooms to encourage a more extended flowering period and prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively. You can deadhead the flowers by cutting them back to a leaf node or lateral bud to promote additional growth and blooming. In late fall or early spring, you may need to trim back dead or damaged stems to maintain a tidy appearance and encourage healthy new growth. Avoid heavy pruning as these plants generally have a delicate structure that should be preserved."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"stiff greenthread","description":"Thelesperma filifolium, commonly known as stiff greenthread, or plains greenthread, is a species of flowering plant in the aster family, Asteraceae. Stiff greenthread adapts to various soil conditions, including loam, clay, caliche, and roadsides. It blooms between March and June and often into the fall.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["stiff greenthread"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Thelesperma filifolium"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Dry"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

However, if the lichen grows over unwanted areas or becomes too dense, you can carefully remove excess growth by gently breaking off parts of the thallus. Always handle with care to prevent damage. Pruning should be minimal, as over-harvesting can harm the lichen's health and growth. "},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cyathea smithii prefers partial to full shade environments mimicking its native forest understory habitat. During its initial establishment period, which is usually the first few years, more frequent watering might be necessary to help the roots grow deep and strong. In general, watering once a week during dry periods should suffice. Take care to water deeply to encourage root growth downwards rather than remaining surface-dependent."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Koelreuteria elegans thrives best in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. When planting, choose a location that receives ample sunlight throughout the day to help the tree establish well and support its potential for reaching its mature size and shape, thus maximizing its aesthetic appeal in the landscape."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Koelreuteria elegans should be done during the late winter or early spring while the tree is dormant. This practice helps maintain its shape and encourage healthy new growth. Remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to maintain an open canopy, which improves air circulation. It's also beneficial to cut back any suckers or aggressive shoots that detract from the tree's desired shape. Make cuts just above the branch collar and at a slight angle to ensure proper healing. Regular pruning helps in maintaining a well-balanced structure, preventing potential split branches or a top-heavy tree."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Taiwanese Rain Tree","description":"Koelreuteria elegans, more commonly known as flamegold or Taiwanese rain tree, is a deciduous tree 15–17 metres tall endemic to Taiwan.
