{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16266,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cupressus forbesii, commonly known as Tecate cypress, prefers infrequent but deep watering to simulate its natural dry habitat. It thrives in well-drained soil and on the drier side once established, requiring less frequent watering. Water deeply every 10 to 14 days during the first couple of years or in prolonged dry conditions. Be cautious not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. Allow the top 2 to 3 inches of soil to dry out between waterings. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce watering frequency."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cupressus forbesii thrives in full sunlight conditions, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. This level of light exposure ensures healthy growth and optimal foliage density. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun encourages its best growth performance and helps the tree develop a strong structure. It is important to avoid locations with heavy shade, as insufficient light can lead to sparse growth and weakened branches. Ideally planted in an open space, this tree will flourish with ample sun throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Cupressus forbesii minimally to maintain its natural form and health. Pruning is generally not required except to remove dead, diseased, or crossing branches. Late winter to early spring is the best time for pruning, before new growth starts. Avoid heavy pruning as this may harm the tree, as it does not heal as readily; only trim branches back to a natural growing point. Regular light pruning can help manage size, encourage denser foliage, and maintain the desired shape. Avoid trimming into older wood as regrowth might be slow."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Tecate cypress","description":"Cupressus forbesii, now reclassified by some as Hesperocyparis forbesii, and with the common names Tecate cypress or Forbes' cypress, is a species of cypress native to southwestern North America.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["California","United States"],"other_name":["Tecate cypress"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal disease"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Cupressus forbesii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If grown in too much shade, the plant may become spindly and have reduced flowering, so finding a sunny spot is key for its success."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Crocanthemum canadense involves removing spent flowers to encourage additional blooming and maintain the plant's appearance. Pruning can be done lightly throughout the growing season to remove dead or damaged growth. This will also help maintain a tidy appearance and prevent the plant from becoming too woody. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to make precise cuts and minimize damage to the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Canada frostweed","description":"Helianthemum canadense or Crocanthemum canadense (known as longbranch frostweed, Canada frostweed, frostweed, rock frost, frostplant, or frostwort) is a species of rock-rose (Cistaceae), native to eastern North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Canada frostweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Crocanthemum canadense"],"soil":["Dry","Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure the soil is kept consistently moist during its active growing season, which is typically in spring and summer. However, it is crucial to avoid overwatering; the soil should not become waterlogged as this can lead to root rot. Allow the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. During its dormant phase, you can reduce the frequency of watering, keeping the soil drier, but not completely dry, to prevent the corms from drying out."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Watsonia borbonica thrives best in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of sunlight per day. Planting it in an area with ample sunlight is crucial for its optimal growth and flowering. Although it can tolerate partial shade, blooming may be less prolific. In hotter climates, providing a little shade during the peak afternoon sunlight can help prevent leaf scorch. If grown indoors or in partial-sun environments, consider supplementing it with grow lights to ensure it receives adequate light, promoting healthy development and vibrant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Watsonia borbonica is generally straightforward. After the flowering period, which occurs in late spring to early summer, it's recommended to deadhead the plant by removing the spent flower spikes. This prevents the plant from putting energy into seed production and encourages healthier growth. Additionally, as the leaves begin to die back naturally, they can be trimmed away to maintain a tidy appearance. Avoid cutting back green foliage as the plant uses these leaves for photosynthesis and energy storage. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bugle-lily","description":"Watsonia borbonica, the Cape bugle-lily, is a species of plant in the family Iridaceae that is native to South Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Bugle-lily"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Watsonia borbonica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16865,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Portulaca grandiflora, commonly known as moss rose, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering. It's important to ensure good drainage to prevent water from pooling around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salvia greggii thrives in full sun conditions, needing at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to produce abundant flowers and maintain vigorous growth. In very hot climates, a location with some light afternoon shade can help protect it from intense mid-day sun and prolong the flowering period. Ensuring the plant enjoys a position with plenty of sunlight will help it maintain a compact, bushy shape and support healthy flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salvia greggii is beneficial to promote bushier growth and to extend the blooming period. Typically, pruning should be done in early spring before new growth begins. Trim back the previous year’s growth, reducing stems by about a third to maintain shape and encourage new growth. Throughout the growing season, deadhead spent flowers to encourage the plant to continue blooming. A light pruning in late summer can also rejuvenate the plant for additional blooms into the fall. Always use clean, sharp tools to make cuts and remove any dead or diseased branches."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"autumn sage","description":"Salvia greggii (autumn sage) is a herbaceous perennial native to a long, narrow area from southwest Texas, through the Chihuahuan Desert and into the Mexican state of San Luis Potosi, typically growing in rocky soils at elevations from 5,000 to 9,000 ft (1,500 to 2,700 m). It was named and described in 1870 by botanist Asa Gray after Josiah Gregg (1806 – 1850), a merchant, explorer, naturalist, and author of the American Southwest and Northern Mexico who found...","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Texas","Mexico"],"other_name":["autumn sage"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Salvia greggii"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18046,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gaultheria depressa, commonly known as the mountain snowberry or alpine waxberry, prefers consistently moist soil, so regular watering is essential, especially during dry periods. However, ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogging, which can harm the plant. If the plant receives morning sun, make sure it gets shade during the hottest parts of the day. When planting indoors, choose a spot with filtered light or near a north or east-facing window. Monitor the plant for signs of sun stress, like wilting or leaf discoloration."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gaultheria depressa is generally minimal but can help maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. Prune after the flowering season in late spring or early summer to remove spent flowers and any dead or damaged branches. Use sharp, clean pruning shears to make clean cuts. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16566,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Kalanchoe daigremontiana, commonly known as the Mother of Thousands, requires careful watering. It is a succulent, so it stores water in its leaves and prefers dry conditions. Water the plant thoroughly when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. It's crucial not to overwater, as soggy soil can lead to root rot. During winter months, reduce watering frequency since the plant's growth slows down and it requires less moisture. Always ensure proper drainage and avoid letting the plant sit in standing water to maintain healthy roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Kalanchoe daigremontiana thrives with plenty of bright, indirect sunlight. Ideally, place the plant in a location where it receives around 6-8 hours of filtered sunlight each day. Direct sunlight exposure, especially during the intense midday hours, should be avoided as it can cause leaf burn. A south or east-facing window is generally ideal. If natural light is insufficient, especially in winter, supplement with artificial grow lights to maintain healthy growth. Regularly rotate the plant to ensure even exposure and prevent leaning towards the light source."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Kalanchoe daigremontiana involves removing any dead or damaged leaves and stems to encourage healthy growth. Additionally, trimming back leggy or excessively long branches can help maintain a compact shape. Use clean and sharp pruning shears to prevent any damage or spread of disease. After flowering, remove spent blooms to keep the plant tidy and encourage new growth. Regular pruning not only enhances the plant's appearance but also promotes more robust growth. Be cautious of the plant’s tiny plantlets, which can root wherever they fall, possibly becoming invasive."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Alligator Plant","description":"Bryophyllum daigremontianum, commonly called devil’s backbone, mother of thousands, alligator plant, or Mexican hat plant is a succulent plant native to Madagascar. Like other members of its genus Bryophyllum, it is able to propagate vegetatively from plantlets that develop on its phylloclade margins. All parts of the plant contain a very toxic steroid known as daigremontianin.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Madagascar"],"other_name":["Alligator Plant"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Kalanchoe daigremontiana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of full sunlight every day for optimal growth and flowering. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent the leaves from scorching. Though it is adaptable to shading conditions, too much shade can lead to sparse flowering and leggy growth. Ensuring it receives adequate sunlight will promote healthier foliage and a more robust plant overall. Observing the plant's response to light and adjusting its exposure accordingly can enhance its growth and flowering potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Fallopia scandens is essential to maintain its shape and control its growth. It is typically pruned in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. You can remove any dead or damaged stems and cut back overly vigorous growth to encourage a more bushy appearance. Regular pruning can prevent the plant from becoming too invasive, as it can spread quickly. Trimming back a third of the growth can stimulate healthy new shoots. It's also beneficial to remove tangled or crossing branches to improve air circulation and light penetration within the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"climbing false buckwheat","description":"Fallopia scandens (climbing false buckwheat) is a species of Fallopia native to North America. It is a herbaceous perennial plant which grows from to 1–5 m (39–197 in) tall. Although they are semi-erect during bloom, when they are producing fruit, they hang from their pedicels in a downward position. Both the fruit and flower are greenish-white in appearance. In North America, it is often misidentified with fallopia dumetorum, a species endemic to Europe.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Eastern North America"],"other_name":["climbing false buckwheat"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Fallopia scandens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17165,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Wisteria floribunda, commonly known as Japanese wisteria, requires moderate watering. It is important to keep the soil consistently moist, especially during its first growing season, to establish a strong root system. However, avoid over-watering as it can lead to root rot. Once established, wisteria is fairly drought-tolerant, but it will bloom more profusely with regular watering. Aim to water deeply once a week during dry periods, ensuring the water reaches deep into the root zone, but allow the top inch of soil to dry out between watering sessions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Wisteria floribunda thrives in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal blooming. While it can tolerate partial shade, its flowering may be significantly reduced. A sunny south or west-facing spot is ideal to ensure the plant receives ample sunlight. If possible, provide exposure to morning sun to help dry off foliage early in the day, reducing the likelihood of diseases. Adequate sunlight encourages robust growth and an abundant display of its beautiful, cascading flowers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is crucial for maintaining the shape and encouraging the blooms of Wisteria floribunda. Prune twice a year: once in late winter and again in the summer. In winter, cut back lateral shoots to 2-3 buds to encourage flower production. Summer pruning involves trimming the long shoots from the current year’s growth back to about six inches, promoting a tidy appearance and future flowering. Regular pruning controls the plant's vigorous growth, prevents it from becoming unmanageable, and helps to enhance the flowering potential."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Japanese wisteria","description":"Wisteria floribunda (common name Japanese wisteria) is a species of flowering plant in the pea family Fabaceae, native to Japan. Growing to 9 m (30 ft), it is a woody, deciduous twining climber. It was brought from Japan to the United States in 1830's. Since then, it has become one of the most highly romanticized flowering garden plants. It is also a common subject for bonsai, along with Wisteria sinensis (Chinese wisteria).","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Japan"],"other_name":["Japanese wisteria"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation","Layering Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Wisteria floribunda"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure good drainage to prevent standing water and mist the plant regularly to increase humidity around it, mimicking its natural moist habitat."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Plagiomnium undulatum prefers shady to partially shaded environments, as it naturally grows under tree canopies and on forest floors. Direct sunlight can be harmful, causing the moss to dry out and become stressed. This will help it to maintain its lush, green appearance and overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is generally not necessary for Plagiomnium undulatum, as mosses grow slowly. However, if you notice any dead or diseased sections, they should be carefully removed to prevent the spread of disease and encourage new growth. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17065,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Thalictrum dasycarpum, commonly known as Purple Meadow-rue, prefers consistently moist soil to thrive. It is important to water this plant regularly, especially during dry periods, to maintain soil moisture. Ensure the soil is well-drained to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. Mulching around the base helps retain soil moisture and keeps roots cool. Reduce watering slightly during the fall and winter when the plant is dormant, but don't allow the soil to completely dry out."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Thalictrum dasycarpum thrives in partial to full sunlight. Ideally, provide the plant with a location where it can receive morning sun and afternoon shade to protect it from the intense midday heat. While it can tolerate full sun in cooler climates, too much direct, intense sunlight can cause leaf scorch and reduced flowering, particularly in hotter zones. Ensure the plant receives at least 4-6 hours of sunlight each day for optimal growth and flowering. Providing too much shade can result in reduced flowering and leggy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Thalictrum dasycarpum is essential to promote healthy growth and flowering. In late winter or early spring, before new growth starts, cut back any dead or damaged stems to the base. During the growing season, remove faded flowers to encourage continued blooming and to prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively. After flowering, you may also trim back the plant to shape it and control its size if necessary. Pruning encourages bushier growth and better air circulation, reducing the risk of fungal diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"purple meadow-rue","description":"Thalictrum dasycarpum, known as tall meadow rue and purple meadow-rue, is a species of flowering plant in the buttercup family, Ranunculaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17859,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Opuntia karwinskiana requires minimal watering as it is a drought-tolerant cactus. Water the plant thoroughly but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. During the growing season (spring and summer), water every two to three weeks. In the dormant period (fall and winter), reduce watering to once a month or even less if the environment is particularly humid. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure proper drainage and avoid letting the plant sit in water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Opuntia karwinskiana thrives in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. It is well-suited to bright, sunny locations such as south or west-facing windowsills. When grown outdoors, choose a sunny spot where the cactus can bask in the sun. Insufficient sunlight can cause the plant to become etiolated, meaning it will grow tall and thin as it stretches toward the light. In very hot climates, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent sunburn."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Opuntia karwinskiana is not entirely necessary unless you want to manage overgrowth or remove damaged pads. Use sterilized pruning shears to cut off any dead, diseased, or excess pads at the joint. Handle the pads carefully as they have sharp spines that can be painful. Pruning in early spring is ideal as it helps the plant direct energy to new growth. Dispose of or propagate healthy pads as desired, and allow cut surfaces to callous over to prevent infection."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","Texas"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":["Scale insects"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Opuntia karwinskiana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17761,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Neobuxbaumia squamulosa is a type of cactus, and like most cacti, it requires infrequent but deep watering. Water this plant thoroughly and allow the soil to dry completely between waterings. Depending on the climate, this might mean watering every 2-3 weeks. During the winter months, reduce watering even further, allowing the cactus to rest as it does in its natural habitat. Over-watering is the most common mistake; always use well-draining cactus soil to prevent waterlogged conditions that could lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Neobuxbaumia squamulosa thrives in bright, direct sunlight, similar to its native desert environment. It should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. If kept indoors, place it near the brightest possible window, preferably a south or west-facing one. If the cactus starts to stretch or becomes thin, it might not be receiving enough light. Gradually acclimate it to direct sun to prevent sunburn if moving it outdoors during warmer months."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Neobuxbaumia squamulosa is generally minimal. As a columnar cactus, it naturally grows upright and doesn’t require much shaping. However, you can remove any dead or damaged parts to encourage healthy growth and prevent disease. Always use clean, sharp tools to minimize stress and the risk of infections. If the cactus starts growing towards a source of light unevenly, consider rotating it to balance its exposure, which can reduce the need for structural cuts."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal diseases"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Neobuxbaumia squamulosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17260,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Zinnia elegans requires regular watering, especially in the peak growing season. It's crucial to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged, which can lead to root rot. Allow the top inch of the soil to dry out between waterings to avoid overwatering. During hot and dry periods, more frequent watering may be necessary. Water at the base of the plant in the morning to keep the foliage dry and minimize the risk of fungal diseases. In container gardens, they may need more frequent watering as potted soil dries out more quickly than ground soil."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Zinnia elegans thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. These plants perform best in sunny locations with ample light, which encourages robust blooms and healthy foliage. Although they can tolerate some shade, insufficient sunlight can lead to fewer flowers and leggy, weak growth. If growing indoors or in areas with limited sunlight, consider placing them under grow lights to supplement natural light and ensure they receive the intensity needed for thriving development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Zinnia elegans primarily involves deadheading, which is the removal of spent or wilted flowers. This practice encourages more blooms and extends the flowering season. To deadhead, cut back each stem to just above a set of leaves or a side branch. Additionally, if the plants become leggy or overgrown, they can be cut back by about one-third of their height to promote bushier growth. Regular pruning helps maintain the plant's shape, improve air circulation, and prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Elegant Zinnia","description":"Zinnia elegans, known as youth-and-age, common zinnia or elegant zinnia, an annual flowering plant of the genus Zinnia, is one of the best known zinnias. It is native to Mexico but grown as an ornamental in many places and naturalised in several places including scattered locations in South and Central America, the West Indies, the United States, Australia, and Italy.","family":null,"flower_color":"Various","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["Elegant Zinnia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Zinnia elegans"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure the soil is consistently damp, especially during its growing season in spring and summer. However, it’s important to avoid waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. If the plant gets too tall and leggy, trimming can help maintain its structure and prevent top-heaviness or tipping over."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"sawtooth sunflower","description":"Helianthus grosseserratus, commonly known as sawtooth sunflower or thick-tooth sunflower , is a perennial sunflower in the family Asteraceae, with a large flowering head (inflorescence).","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Gray\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["sawtooth sunflower"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Helianthus grosseserratus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16961,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salvia microphylla, commonly known as baby sage, requires well-drained soil and should be watered moderately. It's important to allow the soil to dry out between watering to prevent root rot. During the growing season, typically spring through fall, water the plant when the top inch of the soil feels dry. In winter, reduce the frequency as the plant’s growth slows down. Overwatering can be detrimental, so always ensure the plant is not sitting in water. Mulching can help retain moisture but make sure it's done carefully to not keep the soil too moist."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salvia microphylla thrives in full sun but can tolerate partial shade. For optimal growth and blooming, ensure the plant receives at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade will help prevent leaf scorch and maintain vibrant foliage. If grown in partial shade, expect potentially fewer blooms. It's essential to monitor the plant's exposure, especially in areas with very intense sunlight, as too much direct sun without adequate water might stress the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salvia microphylla promotes bushier growth and more blooms. The best time to prune is in early spring before new growth starts. Cut back the previous year's growth by about one-third to one-half, focusing on removing any dead or damaged stems. During the growing season, deadhead spent flowers to encourage continuous blooming. Lightly trim back after flowering if necessary to maintain shape. Additionally, in late fall, remove any diseased or crossing branches to prevent overcrowding and to maintain the health of the plant through winter."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Baby Sage","description":"Salvia microphylla (Baby sage, Graham's sage, Blackcurrant sage) is a perennial shrub found in the wild in southeastern Arizona and the mountains of eastern, western, and southern Mexico. It is a very complex species which easily hybridizes, resulting in numerous hybrids and cultivars brought into horticulture since the 1990s. The specific epithet microphylla, from the Greek, means \"small leaved\". In Mexico, it is called \"mirto de montes,\" or \"myrtle of the mountains.\"","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["Baby Sage"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Salvia microphylla"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16867,"attracts":["Fish"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Potamogeton perfoliatus is an aquatic plant, meaning it thrives entirely in water, making the concept of traditional watering irrelevant. Instead, the focus should be on maintaining its aquatic environment. Ensure the plant is submerged in a suitable water body like a pond or aquarium with clean, fresh water. Regular water changes, maintaining appropriate water pH levels (6.5-8.5), and checking for adequate nutrient availability in the water are essential. Avoid letting the water become stagnant, as good water circulation promotes health and growth in aquatic plants like Potamogeton perfoliatus."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Potamogeton perfoliatus, also known as clasping-leaf pondweed, thrives in full to partial sunlight conditions. Ideally, this aquatic plant needs about 6-8 hours of light each day, either from natural sunlight or artificial grow lights, if kept indoors. If grown in an outdoor pond, ensure it receives enough sunlight without being entirely shaded by taller structures or plants. However, be cautious of excessive heat and direct sun exposure in hotter climates, which could increase water temperature and affect plant health. Balance is key to ensuring optimal growth and health for Potamogeton perfoliatus."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Potamogeton perfoliatus involves trimming the plant to manage its size and promote healthier growth. As an aquatic plant, it can become overgrown, making occasional pruning necessary to prevent it from overtaking your pond or aquarium. Use scissors or an aquatic plant trimmer to remove any dead, damaged, or excess stems. This should be done during its growing season, typically spring to early fall. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16962,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salvia nemorosa, also known as woodland sage, prefers consistently moist soil, especially during its first growing season. It's important to water deeply, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings. After the plant is established, it becomes more drought-tolerant and requires less frequent watering. Avoid overwatering, as soggy soil can lead to root rot. During prolonged dry spells or hot summer months, increase watering frequency to keep the plant healthy. To determine when to water, check the top inch of soil; if it's dry, it's time to water. Ensure good drainage to prevent waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salvia nemorosa thrives best in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. Full sunlight ensures robust growth and abundant flowering. While it can tolerate some light afternoon shade, particularly in hotter climates, insufficient sunlight may lead to leggy growth and reduced bloom production. If planting in a garden, choose a location that receives ample morning sunlight. In areas with harsh afternoon sun, a spot with some protection during the hottest part of the day can be beneficial, but full sun exposure remains optimal for vigor and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salvia nemorosa is essential for promoting a longer blooming season and maintaining a tidy appearance. After the first flush of flowers begins to fade, cut back the flowering stems to encourage a second bloom. In late fall or early spring, perform a more thorough pruning by cutting back the entire plant to just above ground level. This helps rejuvenate the plant for the upcoming growing season. Remove any dead or damaged stems throughout the year to enhance air circulation and plant health. Regular deadheading promotes recurrent blooms and prevents self-seeding."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Purple Wood Sage","description":"Salvia nemorosa (woodland sage, Balkan clary) is a hardy herbaceous perennial plant native to a wide area of central Europe and Western Asia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Purple Wood Sage"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Salvia nemorosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is also important to water the trunk, as this plant absorbs moisture through both its roots and trunk, particularly if the humidity levels are low."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dicksonia fibrosa thrives in partial to full shade, mimicking its natural habitat on the forest floor. It is most effective when limited to the removal of dead or damaged fronds, which should be pruned back in late winter or early spring before new growth appears. Use clean, sharp pruning tools to make cuts close to the main trunk, avoiding cutting into the healthy tissue. This tree fern does not require regular pruning for shaping or size control, and it’s best to let it grow naturally unless fronds are diseased or heavily damaged."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"golden tree fern","description":"Dicksonia fibrosa (common names golden tree fern, and whekī-ponga or kuripaka in Māori) is a species of medium-sized tree fern native to New Zealand.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["golden tree fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Dicksonia fibrosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16470,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Helianthus occidentalis, commonly known as western sunflower, is a drought-tolerant plant that generally prefers moderate watering. It should be watered deeply but infrequently to encourage the growth of a robust root system. Allow the soil to dry out between waterings, especially in areas with high humidity. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to ensure that the plant is not sitting in waterlogged soil. During periods of drought, these plants can survive on minimal water, but they will thrive with a bit of supplementary watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Helianthus occidentalis thrives in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day. This exposure is crucial for optimal flowering and growth. In partial shade, the plant can survive but may exhibit leggier growth and reduced flowering. It's well-suited for prairie gardens, open meadows, or any landscape setting that offers unobstructed sunlight. For best results, plant in a location that captures full morning sun, as this helps prevent mildew and other fungal diseases that can occur in too-shady conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Helianthus occidentalis is generally minimal, as this plant often maintains a tidy appearance on its own. However, deadheading, or the removal of spent blooms, can promote continued flowering throughout the growing season and prevent the plant from going to seed too early. At the end of the growing season, it's beneficial to cut back the stems to about six inches from the ground once they've turned brown, which helps rejuvenate the plant for the next year. Regularly removing dead or damaged foliage also keeps the plant looking its best."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"fewleaf sunflower","description":"Helianthus occidentalis (fewleaf sunflower or western sunflower) is a species of sunflower native to the Eastern and Central United States. It's essential to keep the soil consistently moist, mimicking its natural wetland habitat. This means watering should be regular but not excessive, as waterlogged conditions can lead to root rot. Ensure the plant soil has good drainage and that water does not collect at the bottom of pots if grown indoors. During warmer months, the plant may require more frequent watering, while during the cooler months, watering can be reduced slightly, but never allowing the soil to dry out completely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mitreola petiolata thrives in bright, indirect sunlight, similar to the dappled light it would receive in its native wetland habitat. Direct sunlight can be too intense and might scorch the leaves, so it’s best to avoid placing it in a location where it receives full, direct sunlight for extended periods. If grown indoors, a spot near an east or north-facing window is ideal. During the winter months, when natural light is reduced, consider supplementing with artificial grow lights to ensure the plant receives adequate light to support healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Mitreola petiolata requires minimal pruning, but occasional trimming can help maintain its shape and encourage new growth. Prune away any dead or damaged stems and leaves using sharp, clean scissors or pruning shears to prevent the spread of disease. If the plant becomes too leggy, trim back the overgrown stems to stimulate fuller growth. Pruning is best done in the growing season, which is typically in spring or early summer. Regularly removing spent flowers can also promote a longer blooming period and enhance the overall appearance of the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Lax Hornpod","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Lax Hornpod"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Mitreola petiolata"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Instead, it absorbs moisture from the air and occasional rainfall in its natural settings. If you are growing it in a terrarium or similar setup, ensure that the environment is humid enough to satisfy its needs. Mist the lichen lightly using distilled water to mimic dew or rainwater, only when the surrounding air is overly dry. Avoid overwatering, as lichens are adapted to well-drained conditions and may rot if kept too wet."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Physcia tenella typically thrives in partial to full sunlight, as it can often be found growing on exposed surfaces such as tree bark or rocks. When cultivating this lichen, it's best to replicate its natural environment by placing it where it can receive indirect but consistent sunlight. Direct sunlight, especially during the hottest part of the day, can be too intense and may cause the lichen to dry out excessively. Therefore, a location with filtered light or only morning sun can be ideal to support its growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Physcia tenella does not require much pruning. However, if you want to maintain its shape or remove any dead parts, you can gently trim away the unwanted sections. Use sharp, clean scissors or pruning shears to avoid damaging the lichen. Pruning is generally done to remove the older, less vibrant parts and help maintain its appearance. Do remember that lichens grow slowly, so prune sparingly to avoid removing too much of the organism at once, ensuring you do not interfere with its natural growth pattern."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Fringed Rosette Lichen","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Gray-green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Eurasia","North America"],"other_name":["Fringed Rosette Lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spores"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Physcia tenella"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If the plant becomes too tall or leggy, you can trim the stems down to your desired height. Deadheading, or removing spent flowers, throughout the growing season can encourage further blooming. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17958,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dichromanthus aurantiacus, a terrestrial orchid, requires consistent moisture, but it's important not to overwater. During its active growing period in spring and summer, maintain the soil's moisture by watering once or twice a week, allowing the top inch of soil to partially dry out between waterings. In winter, the plant enters dormancy and requires significantly less water. Reduce watering frequency to once every two weeks or whenever the soil feels dry to the touch. Ensure proper drainage to prevent root rot by using well-draining soil and pots with drainage holes."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dichromanthus aurantiacus thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It prefers environments that mimic the dappled light found on forest floors, making an east or west-facing window ideal. Direct sunlight, especially during the intense midday hours, can scoriate the leaves and damage the plant, causing yellowing or burning. If natural indirect light is insufficient, consider supplementing with fluorescent grow lights. In general, aim to provide about 4-6 hours of indirect light per day. Adjust the plant's position if it shows signs of distress or insufficient lighting."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Dichromanthus aurantiacus involves primarily maintenance trimming. After the flowering period, which typically occurs in summer, remove any spent flower spikes by cutting them back to their base. This will encourage new growth and help the plant conserve energy. Additionally, periodically check for and remove any yellowing or dead leaves to improve airflow and overall plant health. Avoid excessive pruning, as the plant doesn't require shaping. Use sterilized pruning scissors to prevent the spread of disease and focus on keeping the plant tidy and healthy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":"Dichromanthus aurantiacus is a terrestrial species of orchid. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17167,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Xanthorhiza simplicissima, commonly known as yellowroot, prefers consistently moist but well-drained soil. It's important to mimic its natural woodland habitat by keeping the soil lightly moist without allowing it to become waterlogged. During the growing season, water the plant regularly, making sure to allow the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. In winter, reduce watering as the plant enters dormancy. A layer of organic mulch can help retain moisture, especially during dry summer periods. Always adjust watering based on local climate conditions and seasonal changes."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Xanthorhiza simplicissima thrives in partial to full shade, aligning with its natural habitat under tree canopies in woodland settings. It can tolerate dappled sunlight or a few hours of morning sun, but too much direct sunlight can lead to scorched leaves. In areas with hot summers, ensure it's planted in a location that provides afternoon shade. Despite being shade-tolerant, the plant will benefit from some light exposure, aiding in plentiful and vibrant foliage growth. If growing indoors, place it near a north or east-facing window for optimal light conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Yellowroot requires minimal pruning, but occasional maintenance can help keep the plant tidy and healthy. Prune away any dead or damaged stems throughout the growing season to maintain appearance and prevent disease. Additionally, thinning out crowded areas can improve air circulation, reducing the risk of fungal issues. In early spring, before new growth appears, you can cut back older stems to the ground to encourage new, vigorous shoots. It is important to water the plant regularly to maintain the dampness of the soil, especially during dry spells or in well-drained garden locations. During the active growth period in spring and summer, monitor the soil moisture carefully to prevent it from drying out. In general, watering once a week is beneficial, increasing the frequency whenever the upper layer of the soil starts to feel dry. Ensure good drainage to avoid water stagnation at the roots, which can lead to root rot, by enhancing the soil with organic matter or mulch."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lysimachia borealis thrives in partial to full shade conditions, making it well-suited for woodland gardens or shaded parts of your landscape. Although it can tolerate some morning light, exposure to harsh, direct sunlight, particularly in the afternoon, should be avoided as it might lead to leaf scorching. If you notice the leaves turning pale or scorched, consider relocating the plant to a shadier spot. Ensuring the right amount of light is crucial for its lush growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Lysimachia borealis is not often necessary, as it naturally sustains a tidy growth habit. Trim back any overly aggressive growth, although this plant usually behaves well without becoming invasive. Lastly, ensure your pruning tools are sterilized before use to prevent the spread of diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"northern starflower","description":"Lysimachia borealis (synonym Trientalis borealis), the starflower, is a North American woodland perennial that blooms between May and June.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["northern starflower"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Lysimachia borealis"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Snipping off the flower stems can also encourage the plant to produce more leaves rather than focusing its energy on flowering. Always use clean, sharp scissors to make cuts and do so just above a node to stimulate new growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Mexican Culantro","description":"Eryngium foetidum is a tropical perennial herb in the family Apiaceae. It is native to Mexico and South America, but is cultivated worldwide, sometimes being grown as an annual in temperate climates. If growing indoors, supplementing with a grow light can help during seasons with shorter daylight hours. This light requirement mimics their natural desert environment, ensuring optimal health and growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Mammillaria carnea is generally minimal and primarily focused on maintaining its shape and removing any dead or damaged parts. If offshoots or pups have developed and you wish to propagate them separately, they can be gently removed with a sterile knife for new plant growth. Remove any dead flowers by carefully plucking or cutting them off to conserve energy and maintain appearance. Always use clean, sharp tools to avoid introducing diseases or pathogens to the plant during the pruning process."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":null,"description":"Mammillaria carnea is a species of cactus in the subfamily Cactoideae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Mammillaria carnea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During its growing season, especially in hotter weather, regular watering is important to maintain soil moisture. However, it is drought-tolerant once established, meaning that occasional dry periods are tolerated. To promote healthy growth, ensure the soil dries out slightly between watering sessions, as overwatering can lead to root rot. Mulching can help retain moisture and reduce watering frequency. Always take care to adjust the watering schedule based on local climate conditions and rainfall."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Helianthus strumosus thrives best in full sun conditions, receiving at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. This exposure ensures vigorous flowering and healthy growth. While it can tolerate partial shade, the blooming might not be as prolific, and the plant may become leggy as it reaches for more light. When planted in shadier locations, ensure the soil drainage is optimal to prevent any moisture-related issues. If you are growing it in an area with intense sunlight, providing afternoon shade might help to prevent foliage scalding, especially in very hot climates."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Helianthus strumosus involves removing any dead or damaged leaves and stems throughout the growing season to encourage healthy, robust growth. After the flowering period, which typically occurs in late summer to fall, cut back the spent flowers to prevent the plant from self-seeding if seed production is not desired. A more extensive pruning can be done in late winter or early spring to remove any dead plant material and to tidy up the appearance before new growth begins. This also helps in controlling the size and spread of the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"pale-leaved woodland sunflower","description":"Helianthus hirsutus is a North American species of sunflower known by the common name hairy sunflower. It is widespread across south-central Canada, the eastern and central United States, and northeastern Mexico. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18048,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Phyllachne colensoi, commonly known as a cushion plant, thrives best in moist environments. To properly care for this plant, it is crucial to maintain a balance in moisture levels. Ensure that the soil remains consistently damp but not waterlogged, as excess water can lead to root rot. It is advisable to water the plant whenever the top layer of soil begins to dry. During hot weather, more frequent watering may be necessary to prevent the soil from drying out. Implementing a well-draining soil mix will also help prevent water from accumulating excessively around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phyllachne colensoi prefers environments that provide partial to full sunlight exposure, similar to its native alpine habitats. For optimal growth, this cushion plant should be placed in a location that receives bright, indirect sunlight most of the day. Direct sunlight during the hottest part of the day can be too intense, so providing some afternoon shade may be necessary to prevent scorching, particularly in warm climates. If grown indoors, placing the plant near a north or east-facing window will typically offer an ideal balance of light. Adjust lighting conditions as needed to mimic these preferences."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phyllachne colensoi is generally minimal due to its cushion-like growth form. However, to ensure healthy growth and maintain its compact shape, occasional pruning can be beneficial. Remove any dead or discolored leaves to improve air circulation within the plant, which helps prevent disease. Pruning should be done carefully to avoid harming the dense cushion structure. It's best to use clean, sharp scissors to avoid tearing the plant tissue. Routine inspection of the plant will help identify any areas that may benefit from pruning to promote overall health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"yellow cushionplant","description":"Phyllachne colensoi, the yellow cushionplant, is a species of cushion plant in the Stylidiaceae family. It is native to both New Zealand and Tasmania, with colonisation of the latter being a somewhat recent dispersal. Phyllachne colensoi is frequently the dominant vegetation in upland bog habitats and is found throughout high mountain areas in New Zealand, but is only recorded from 12 sites in Tasmania in the west and south-west of the island.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["yellow cushionplant"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Phyllachne colensoi"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17067,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Thelesperma filifolium, commonly known as Greenthread, is drought-tolerant and requires minimal watering once established. Water it deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. It's crucial not to overwater, as this plant prefers dry conditions and can suffer from root rot if kept too moist. During the first growing season, regular watering helps the plant develop a strong root system, but once mature, it can endure prolonged dry periods. In container settings, ensure proper drainage to prevent waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Thelesperma filifolium thrives best in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day to ensure robust growth and vibrant flowering. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight may lead to leggy growth and reduced blooming. When choosing a planting site, consider open areas like gardens or meadows, where the plant can receive uninterrupted sunlight. In indoor settings, place it near a south or west-facing window to maximize light exposure. Overall, ensuring plenty of sunlight is crucial for its optimal health and flower production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Thelesperma filifolium involves removing spent blooms to encourage a more extended flowering period and prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively. You can deadhead the flowers by cutting them back to a leaf node or lateral bud to promote additional growth and blooming. In late fall or early spring, you may need to trim back dead or damaged stems to maintain a tidy appearance and encourage healthy new growth. Avoid heavy pruning as these plants generally have a delicate structure that should be preserved."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"stiff greenthread","description":"Thelesperma filifolium, commonly known as stiff greenthread, or plains greenthread, is a species of flowering plant in the aster family, Asteraceae. It is often found growing in shallow soils. It prefers disturbed sites in dry, sandy or gravelly soil with a neutral to basic pH. Stiff greenthread adapts to various soil conditions, including loam, clay, caliche, and roadsides. It blooms between March and June and often into the fall.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["stiff greenthread"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Thelesperma filifolium"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Dry"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17467,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lysimachia maritima, commonly known as Sea Milkwort, prefers moist conditions but can tolerate periods of dryness once established. It's important to keep the soil consistently damp, especially during the warmer months. During the active growing season, aim to water the plant thoroughly whenever the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch. However, ensure that the plant is not sitting in waterlogged soil, as this can lead to root rot. In the winter months, when growth slows, reduce watering but do not let the soil completely dry out."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lysimachia maritima thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to promote healthy growth and flowering. However, in regions with extremely hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. If planted in areas with more shade, the plant may grow well but could produce fewer flowers. When choosing a planting location, aim for a spot that balances sunlight availability with protection from the harshest midday sun."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Lysimachia maritima involves trimming back the stems to maintain a tidy appearance and encourage bushier growth. You can prune back dead or damaged stems at any time of the year, cutting just above a leaf node to stimulate new growth. In early spring, before new growth starts, you can perform a more significant pruning to maintain the desired shape and size of the plant. Regularly removing spent flowers will encourage continuous blooming throughout the growing season. Always use clean, sharp tools to avoid introducing diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Sea Milkwort","description":"Lysimachia maritima is a species belonging to the family Primulaceae. It was previously called Glaux maritima, the only species in the monotypic genus Glaux. The species has a number of common names, including sea milkwort, sea milkweed, and black saltwort.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Europe"],"other_name":["Sea Milkwort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Lysimachia maritima"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17662,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Psora crenata is a lichen, which is a symbiotic association between a fungus and an alga or cyanobacterium. As a lichen, it typically doesn't require traditional watering like vascular plants. Instead, it absorbs moisture from the atmosphere, such as rain, dew, or humidity. In cultivation or lichen gardens, it is important to mimic its natural environment by occasionally misting it with water, especially during dry periods, to prevent desiccation. Avoid over-watering, as this can lead to detrimental growth conditions or mold."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Psora crenata, like many lichens, requires a specific balance of sunlight and shade. It typically thrives in environments where it receives filtered or indirect sunlight, as direct exposure to intense sunlight can cause desiccation. In natural settings, it is often found on surfaces where light conditions vary. When cultivating this lichen, try to simulate its natural habitat by providing dappled lighting, ensuring it receives enough light for photosynthesis without excessive heat or light stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Psora crenata is generally not necessary, as lichens do not grow in the same way as traditional plants. However, if the lichen grows over unwanted areas or becomes too dense, you can carefully remove excess growth by gently breaking off parts of the thallus. Always handle with care to prevent damage. Pruning should be minimal, as over-harvesting can harm the lichen's health and growth. It is important to maintain a balance that allows for natural growth and aesthetic preference."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"brick scale","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Grey"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Europe"],"other_name":["brick scale"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Psora crenata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17365,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cyathea smithii, commonly known as the soft tree fern, thrives in consistently moist soil. It prefers high humidity and regular watering; ensure the soil is kept evenly moist but not waterlogged to prevent root rot. Water the plant deeply, especially during dry periods, early in the morning or late in the afternoon to reduce evaporation. In container settings, consistent irrigation will be necessary, and misting the fronds can help maintain the humidity levels. During winter, while growth slows, reduce watering slightly to prevent over-saturation without letting the soil dry out completely. "},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cyathea smithii prefers partial to full shade environments mimicking its native forest understory habitat. It thrives under filtered light, similar to what it would receive beneath a forest canopy. Direct sunlight can scorch the delicate fronds, so avoid placing it in locations with intense sun exposure. If growing indoors or in a greenhouse, consider using sheer curtains or placing the plant in dappled light. In outdoor environments, situate the plant in places where it can receive morning light but is protected from harsh afternoon sun rays. Ideal placement would offer bright, indirect light throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cyathea smithii involves removing dead or damaged fronds to maintain its aesthetic appeal and promote healthy growth. Trim fronds close to the trunk with sharp, sterilized tools to prevent disease. Avoid cutting healthy fronds, as they contribute to the plant's overall health and energy production. During the growing season, routinely check the plant for old foliage and trim away yellowing or browning fronds. Regularly clearing the plant of debris also discourages pest activity and helps in inspecting for any potential diseases or problems early on."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Smith's tree fern","description":"Cyathea smithii, commonly known as the soft tree fern or kātote, is a species of tree fern from New Zealand.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Smith's tree fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spores"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Cyathea smithii"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16569,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Koelreuteria elegans, commonly known as the Flamegold or Goldenrain tree, prefers moderate watering. During its initial establishment period, which is usually the first few years, more frequent watering might be necessary to help the roots grow deep and strong. In general, watering once a week during dry periods should suffice. Take care to water deeply to encourage root growth downwards rather than remaining surface-dependent."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Koelreuteria elegans thrives best in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. This exposure ensures healthy growth and vibrant flowering. It can tolerate partial shade, but with less enthusiasm in blooming and overall vitality. Full sun is preferred to maintain its ornamental features, such as the bright yellow flowers and colorful autumn foliage. When planting, choose a location that receives ample sunlight throughout the day to help the tree establish well and support its potential for reaching its mature size and shape, thus maximizing its aesthetic appeal in the landscape."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Koelreuteria elegans should be done during the late winter or early spring while the tree is dormant. This practice helps maintain its shape and encourage healthy new growth. Remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to maintain an open canopy, which improves air circulation. It's also beneficial to cut back any suckers or aggressive shoots that detract from the tree's desired shape. Make cuts just above the branch collar and at a slight angle to ensure proper healing. Regular pruning helps in maintaining a well-balanced structure, preventing potential split branches or a top-heavy tree."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Taiwanese Rain Tree","description":"Koelreuteria elegans, more commonly known as flamegold or Taiwanese rain tree, is a deciduous tree 15–17 metres tall endemic to Taiwan. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17763,"attracts":["Birds","Insects"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Isolatocereus dumortieri, like most cacti, requires infrequent watering. It is crucial to allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot, a common problem with overwatered cactus plants. During the growing season in spring and summer, water the cactus thoroughly every 2-3 weeks. Reduce watering to once a month or less during fall and winter when the plant is in its dormant phase. Always use well-draining cactus soil to prevent water from sitting around the roots, which can lead to fungal issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Isolatocereus dumortieri thrives in abundant sunlight and should receive full sun for at least 6 to 8 hours a day. It is best suited for outdoor environments or sun-drenched indoor spaces, such as a south-facing window. Ensure gradual exposure to direct sunlight, especially if the cactus has been kept in lower light conditions, to prevent sunburn. During the summer, you can move the plant outdoors where it can bask in natural light, but avoid sudden exposure to extreme temperatures or intense midday sun without some acclimatization."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Isolatocereus dumortieri is generally not required unless you want to remove any damaged or diseased parts. If necessary, prune the cactus in the spring before its active growth period. Use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and minimize damage to the plant. Avoid removing any healthy sections unnecessarily, as this cactus grows slowly and pruning could set back its development. Always wear gloves when handling this cactus to protect against its spines, and consider using tongs or other tools to handle the plant when pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":"Stenocereus dumortieri is a flowering plant in the family Cactaceae that is found in Querétaro, Mexico at elevations of 1800 meters.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Isolatocereus dumortieri"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17959,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dietes grandiflora, also known as the African iris, requires moderate watering. It is important to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged, particularly during the plant’s active growing period in spring and summer. Watering should be reduced in the winter months when the plant enters a more dormant phase. Ensure the soil has good drainage to prevent root rot. A well-draining soil mix will help maintain the right moisture balance, as standing water can harm the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dietes grandiflora thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and flowering. However, in very hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent the leaves from scorching. While the plant can tolerate partial shade, too much shade may result in fewer flowers and leggy growth. Therefore, choose a planting location that balances sunlight and shade based on the local climate conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dietes grandiflora involves removing dead or damaged leaves and spent flower stalks throughout the growing season. This not only improves the plant's appearance but also encourages new growth and flowering. After the flowers fade, cut the flower stalks down to the base to prevent the plant from expending energy on seed production. Additionally, a more substantial pruning can be done in the early spring to remove old foliage, which can help rejuvenate the plant and maintain its shape."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Large Fortnight Lily","description":"Dietes grandiflora (large wild iris, fairy iris) is a rhizomatous perennial plant with long, rigid, sword-like green leaves belonging to the Iridaceae family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17566,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sedum dendroideum, commonly known as tree sedum, is a drought-tolerant succulent. It prefers infrequent watering, allowing the soil to dry out completely between watering sessions. During the growing season in spring and summer, water the plant approximately every 10-14 days. In the cooler months of fall and winter, reduce watering to once a month or less, depending on the climate. Ensure that the pot has adequate drainage to prevent waterlogged soil, which can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sedum dendroideum thrives in bright, direct sunlight and should be placed in a location where it receives full sun for several hours a day. Ideally, aim for at least six hours of sunlight. In climates with extremely hot sun, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. If grown indoors, place the plant near a south- or west-facing window with ample light exposure. Adequate sunlight is crucial for the plant's growth and to maintain its vibrant, healthy appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sedum dendroideum is not frequently necessary, but it can help maintain the plant's shape and encourage healthy growth. Trim back leggy branches in early spring before new growth starts, using clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears. Additionally, removing any dead or damaged leaves as they appear can keep the plant tidy and prevent diseases. Pruning also helps stimulate branching and can promote a denser plant. Always leave some leaves on each stem to allow for photosynthesis and regrowth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Tree Stonecrop","description":"Sedum dendroideum, commonly known as the tree stonecrop or the false hens-and-chickens, is a shrub-like perennial plant that looks much like its Sempervivum look-alike. Native to Mexico, Sedum dendroideum plant thrives in warm, arid climates, as well as in cooler climates. It has been naturalized to California, and Ohio.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["Tree Stonecrop"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Mealybugs"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Sedum dendroideum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16963,"attracts":["Hummingbirds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salvia regla, commonly known as the mountain sage, prefers moderate watering. Allow the soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot, as this plant does not like to sit in soggy soil. During the growing season, water the plant once or twice a week, depending on rainfall and temperature. In the winter months, reduce watering to once every ten to fourteen days, as the plant enters a dormant phase and requires less moisture. Ensure good drainage in the pot or garden bed to maintain soil conditions conducive to healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salvia regla thrives in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. It performs best when planted in a location that receives plenty of bright light to support its vibrant blooms and healthy foliage. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from extreme heat. However, too much shade can result in leggy growth and reduced flowering. Position the plant in a spot that balances sunlight with protection from the harshest rays during the peak of summer."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salvia regla is essential for maintaining its shape and promoting bushier growth. After blooming in late summer or fall, deadhead the spent flowers to encourage more blooms and tidy up the plant. In early spring, perform a heavy pruning, cutting back the stems by one-third to one-half. This helps to remove any dead or damaged wood and stimulates new growth in the growing season. Avoid heavy pruning in late fall, as this could lead to frost damage in colder climates where the plant is not hardy."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Mountain Sage","description":"Salvia regla (Mountain sage) is a deciduous perennial that is native to a small area of the Chisos Mountains in west Texas and a large area of Mexico, in the states of Coahuila, Durango, and Oaxaca. The specific epithet is probably from the town of Regla in the state of Hidalgo. It is also referred to as the \"queen of the Chisos Mountains\". It has been widely planted along the Texas flyway for migrating birds, and...","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["Mountain Sage"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Salvia regla"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Always use a well-draining potting mix to facilitate proper drying of the soil between watering sessions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Opuntia pubescens thrives in full sunlight conditions, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. If grown in low-light conditions, the plant may become leggy or have slowed growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Opuntia pubescens is generally minimal but can be done to remove dead or damaged pads and to manage size or shape. After pruning, allow the cut areas to scab over and dry before replanting or watering to prevent infection or rot. It's important not to overwater as Eryngium species are somewhat drought-tolerant once established. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Ensure good drainage to prevent root rot, which can be a problem in poorly drained soils. During the growing season, regular watering can support healthy growth, but reduce watering in the winter when the plant is dormant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eryngium heterophyllum thrives in full sunlight and requires at least six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and blooming. While it does best in full sun, it can tolerate some light shade, especially in hotter climates where afternoon sun may be intense. Providing adequate sunlight ensures the plant maintains its characteristic robust growth and vibrant colors. In inadequate light, the plant might become leggy and produce fewer blooms, so prioritize bright, sunny locations."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Eryngium heterophyllum is generally not required beyond removing spent flower stalks to encourage a tidy appearance. After flowering, cut back the stems to promote new growth and possibly a second round of flowering. In late winter or early spring, remove any dead or damaged foliage to maintain plant health and aesthetics. Be cautious when handling Eryngium, as the stems can be quite sharp. Avoid heavy pruning, as the plant’s architectural form is part of its appeal."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Wright's eryngo","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Southwestern United States"],"other_name":["Wright's eryngo"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Eryngium heterophyllum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
